title: Antibiotic use in livestock in Europe
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/antibiotic-use-in-livestock-in-europe?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Antibiotics are used in livestock for animal health and productivity, but also pose a risk for antibiotic resistance in both humans and livestock. Data is measured as the milligrams of total antibiotic use per kilogram of meat production. This is corrected for differences in livestock numbers and types, normalising to a population-corrected unit (PCU). A suggested global cap of antibiotic use in livestock is set at 50mg/PCU.

title: Antibiotic use in livestock vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/antibiotic-use-in-livestock-vs-gdp-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Antibiotic use in livestock vs. meat supply per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/antibiotic-use-in-livestock-vs-meat-supply-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Antibiotic use in livestock, measured as the milligrams of total active ingredient used per kilogram of meat production versus the average meat supply per capita, measured in kilograms per person per year.

title: Global antibiotic use in livestock under reduction scenarios
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/reduction-global-antibiotic-use?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Projected global antibiotic use in livestock under expected meat consumption levels in 2030, and a range of modeled reduction scenarios based on antibiotic use limits, reductions in meat consumption, and a fee on antibiotic sales. Further details on each scenario are given in the sources tab. Global antibiotic use is measured in tonnes per year.

subtitle: English- and Chinese-language scholarly publications related to the development and application of AI. This includes journal articles, conference papers, repository publications (such as arXiv), books, and theses.

title: Artificial intelligence: Performance on knowledge tests vs. dataset size
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/ai-performance-knowledge-tests-vs-dataset-size?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Performance on knowledge tests is measured with the MMLU benchmark, here with 5-shot learning, which gauges a model’s accuracy after receiving only five examples for each task. Training dataset size refers to the volume of text that is employed to train a model effectively.

title: Artificial intelligence: Performance on knowledge tests vs. number of parameters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/ai-performance-knowledge-tests-vs-parameters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Performance on knowledge tests is measured with the MMLU benchmark, here with 5-shot learning, which gauges a model’s accuracy after receiving only five examples for each task. Parameters are variables in an AI system whose values are adjusted during training to establish how input data gets transformed into the desired output; for example, the connection weights in an artificial neural network.

title: Artificial intelligence: Performance on knowledge tests vs. training computation
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/ai-performance-knowledge-tests-vs-training-computation?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Performance on knowledge tests is measured with the MMLU benchmark, here with 5-shot learning, which gauges a model’s accuracy after receiving only five examples for each task. Training computation is measured in total petaFLOP, which is 10¹⁵ floating-point operations.

title: Chess ability of the best computers
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/computer-chess-ability?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Chess ability is measured with the Elo rating system, which is calculated based on game results. A higher rating indicates that a player is more likely to win a game.

title: Computation used to train notable AI systems, by affiliation of researchers
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/artificial-intelligence-training-computation-by-researcher-affiliation?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Computation is measured in total petaFLOP, which is 10¹⁵ floating-point operations estimated from AI literature, albeit with some uncertainty. Estimates are expected to be accurate within a factor of 2, or a factor of 5 for recent undisclosed models like GPT-4.

title: Computation used to train notable artificial intelligence systems
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/artificial-intelligence-training-computation?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Computation is measured in total petaFLOP, which is 10¹⁵ floating-point operations. Estimated from AI literature, albeit with some uncertainty. Estimates are expected to be accurate within a factor of 2, or a factor of 5 for recent undisclosed models like GPT-4.

title: Countries with national artificial intelligence strategies

title: Domain of notable artificial intelligence systems, by year of publication

title: Fish stocks and fishing intensity by group
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-stocks-taxa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish stocks are measured by biomass: the number of individuals multiplied by their mass. Fishing intensity by the fraction of the fish population that is caught in a given year. Both are given as a ratio of their levels at the maximum sustainable yield – the level at which we can catch the maximum amount of fish without a decline in fish populations. A value of one maximises fish catch without decreasing fish populations. This is the target level.

title: Fish stocks and fishing intensity by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-stocks-by-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish stocks are measured by biomass: the number of individuals multiplied by their mass. Fishing intensity by the fraction of the fish population that is caught in a given year. Both are given as a ratio of their levels at the maximum sustainable yield – the level at which we can catch the maximum amount of fish without a decline in fish populations. A value of one maximises fish catch without decreasing fish populations. This is the target level.

title: Fishing intensity
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fishing-pressure-by-taxa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fishing intensity measured the extent to which a stock is being exploited. This is the fraction of the fish population that is caught in a given year. Here it's measured as the intensity divided by the intensity at the maximum sustainable yield – the level at which we can catch the maximum amount of fish without a decline in fish populations. A value of one is the optimal level to maximize fish catch without declining populations. Greater than one suggests overfishing.

title: Fishing intensity by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fishing-pressure-by-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fishing intensity measures the extent to which a stock is being exploited. Here, it's measured as current fishing intensity divided by the intensity at the maximum sustainable yield. A value of one is the optimal level to maximize fish catch without causing fish population. Greater than one suggests overfishing.

subtitle: Global biomass (measured in tonnes of carbon) versus the abundance (number of individuals) of different taxonomic groups. These are given as order-of-magnitude estimates.

title: Global wildlife exports
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/wildlife-exports?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Wildlife trade is quantified in terms of whole organism equivalents (WOE). For example, five skulls represent five WOEs, whereas it's assumed that four ears are sourced from two animals and so represent two WOEs.

title: Health of fish stocks by fish group
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/biomass-fish-stocks-taxa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish stocks are measured by their biomass: the number of individuals multiplied by their mass. Here it's measured as the biomass of a fish stock divided by the biomass at its maximum sustainable yield – the level at which we can catch the maximum amount of fish without a decline in fish populations. A value of one maximises fish catch without decreasing fish populations.

title: Health of fish stocks by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/biomass-fish-stocks-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish stocks are measured by their biomass: the number of individuals multiplied by their mass. Here the biomass of a fish stock is divided by the biomass at its maximum sustainable yield. A value of one maximizes fish catch without decreasing fish populations.

title: Indian rhino population
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/indian-rhinos?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Living Planet Index

subtitle: The Living Planet Index (LPI) measures the average decline in monitored wildlife populations. The index value measures the change in abundance in 31,821 populations across 5,230 species relative to the year 1970 (i.e. 1970 = 100%).

title: Living Planet Index by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/living-planet-index-by-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The Living Planet Index (LPI) measures the average relative decline in monitored wildlife populations. The index value measures the change in abundance in 38,427 populations across 5,268 species relative to the year 1970 (i.e. 1970 = 100%).

title: Local animal breeds with conserved genetic material

subtitle: The number of local animal breeds, those that exist in only one country, with sufficient genetic material stored within genebank collections to allow the reconstitution of the breed in case of extinction.

title: Material footprint per capita

subtitle: Material footprint is the quantity of material needed to meet a country's material demand. It is material production, adjusted for trade. The total material footprint is the sum of the material footprint for biomass, fossil fuels, metal ores, and non-metal ores, given in tonnes per year.

title: Material footprint per unit of GDP
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/material-footprint-per-unit-of-gdp?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Material footprint is the quantity of material needed to meet a country's material demand. It is material production, adjusted for trade. The total material footprint is the sum of the material footprint for biomass, fossil fuels, metal ores, and non-metal ores.

title: Member countries of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/countries-to-the-international-treaty-on-plant-genetic-resources?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture is an international agreement that aims to ensure the conservation and sustainable use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, and to promote the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits derived from their use.

title: Mountain Green Cover Index
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/mountain-green-cover-index?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Mountain Green Cover Index measures the share of mountainous areas covered by either forest, cropland, grassland or wetland. An increase in green mountain cover may reflect either the expansion of natural ecosystems or an increase in the growth of vegetation in areas previously covered by glaciers.

title: National biodiversity strategy and action plan targets align with Aichi Biodiversity Target 9

subtitle: Aichi Target 9: By 2020, invasive alien species and pathways are identified and prioritized, priority species are controlled or eradicated and measures are in place to manage pathways to prevent their introduction and establishment.

title: National progress towards Aichi Biodiversity Target 2
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/national-progress-towards-aichi-biodiversity-target-2?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

subtitle: Coral bleaching typically occurs when water temperatures rise above the normal range for the coral's habitat. This is more likely during El Niño stages of the ENSO cycle when tropical sea temperatures are warmer.

title: Total disease burden

subtitle: The total disease burden is measured as the number of Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) per year. DALYs measure the total burden of disease – both from years of life lost due to premature death and years lived with a disability. One DALY equals one lost year of healthy life.

title: Total disease burden by cause

subtitle: Total disease burden measured as Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) per year. DALYs measure the total burden of disease – both from years of life lost due to premature death and years lived with a disability. One DALY equals one lost year of healthy life.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/tuberculosis-cases-attributable-to-risk-factors?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Estimated annual number of tuberculosis cases that are attributable to certain risk factors.

title: Contribution to value added vs. share of CO2 emissions in Germany

title: Contribution to value added vs. share of CO2 emissions in USA

subtitle: Contribution of individual sectors to net economic output versus its share of total national carbon dioxide (CO₂) emissions in 2009. title: Countries using the System of Environmental-Economic Accounting

subtitle: Gross domestic product (GDP) growth of individual sectors (adjusted for inflation) versus growth in carbon dioxide (CO₂) emissions over the period 1995-2009. Sectors in the top left quadrant have decoupled their emissions from economic growth - whilst their emissions fell, their economic value grew. Direct emissions of households are not included.

title: Value added growth vs. CO2 emissions growth in Germany
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/value-added-growth-vs-emissions-growth-germany?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Gross domestic product (GDP) growth of individual sectors (adjusted for inflation) versus growth in carbon dioxide (CO₂) emissions over the period 1995-2009. Sectors in the top left quadrant have decoupled their emissions from economic growth - whilst their emissions fell, their economic value grew. Direct emissions of households are not included.

title: Value added growth vs. CO2 emissions growth in the USA
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/value-added-growth-vs-emissions-growth-usa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Gross domestic product (GDP) growth of individual sectors (adjusted for inflation) versus growth in carbon dioxide (CO₂) emissions over the period 1995-2009. Sectors in the top left quadrant have decoupled their emissions from economic growth - whilst their emissions fell, their economic value grew. Direct emissions of households are not included.

title: Which countries have a carbon emissions trading system?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/carbon-emissions-trading-system?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: A country is marked as having an emissions trading system (ETS) if at least one sector is covered by one.

title: Which countries have a carbon tax?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/carbon-tax-instruments?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: A country is marked as having a carbon emissions tax instrument if at least one sector has implemented one.

title: Which countries have set a net-zero emissions target?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/net-zero-target-set?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Countries are shown as having a net-zero emissions target if they have: achieved net-zero already; have it written in law; in their policy document or have made a public pledge. The year for which countries have pledged to achieve net-zero varies.

title: Year-on-year change in CO2 emissions
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/absolute-change-co2?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Absolute annual change in carbon dioxide (CO₂) emissions, measured in tonnes.

title: Are children eligible for COVID-19 vaccination?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/covid-vaccine-age?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The youngest age threshold eligible for vaccination in each age group may vary. For example, a country coded as "available to under-16s" may only offer vaccination to children aged five years and older.

title: Biweekly change in confirmed COVID-19 cases
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/biweekly-growth-covid-cases?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The biweekly change on any given date measures the percentage change in the number of new confirmed cases over the last 14 days, relative to the number in the previous 14 days. Due to limited testing, the number of confirmed cases is lower than the true number of infections.

title: Biweekly change in confirmed COVID-19 deaths
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/biweekly-change-covid-deaths?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The biweekly change on any given date measures the percentage change in the number of new confirmed deaths over the last 14 days relative to the number in the previous 14 days. Due to varying protocols and challenges in the attribution of the cause of death, the number of confirmed deaths may not accurately represent the true number of deaths caused by COVID-19.

title: Biweekly confirmed COVID-19 cases
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/biweekly-confirmed-covid-19-cases?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Biweekly confirmed cases refer to the cumulative number of confirmed cases over the previous two weeks.

title: Biweekly confirmed COVID-19 cases per million people
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/biweekly-covid-cases-per-million-people?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Biweekly confirmed cases refers to the cumulative number of cases over the previous two weeks. Due to limited testing, the number of confirmed cases is lower than the true number of infections.

title: Biweekly confirmed COVID-19 deaths
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/biweekly-covid-deaths?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Cumulative number of confirmed deaths over the previous two weeks. Due to varying protocols and challenges in the attribution of the cause of death, the number of confirmed deaths may not accurately represent the true number of deaths caused by COVID-19.

title: Biweekly confirmed COVID-19 deaths per million people
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/biweekly-covid-deaths-per-million-people?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Biweekly confirmed deaths refer to the cumulative number of confirmed deaths over the previous two weeks. Due to varying protocols and challenges in the attribution of the cause of death, the number of confirmed deaths may not accurately represent the true number of deaths caused by COVID-19.

title: COVID-19 Containment and Health Index
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/covid-containment-and-health-index?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: This is a composite measure based on thirteen policy response indicators including school closures, workplace closures, travel bans, testing policy, contact tracing, face coverings, and vaccine policy rescaled to a value from 0 to 100 (100 = strictest). If policies vary at the subnational level, the index is shown as the response level of the strictest sub-region.

title: COVID-19 testing policies
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/covid-19-testing-policy?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: – No testing policy. – Only those who both (a) have symptoms and also (b) meet specific criteria (e.g. key workers, admitted to hospital, came into contact with a known case, returned from overseas). – Testing of anyone showing COVID-19 symptoms. – Open public testing (e.g. “drive through” testing available to asymptomatic people).

title: COVID-19 vaccination policy
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/covid-vaccination-policy?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Policies for vaccine delivery. Vulnerable groups include key workers, the clinically vulnerable, and the elderly. "Others" include select broad groups, such as by age.

title: COVID-19 vaccinations vs. COVID-19 deaths

subtitle: Total vaccine doses administered per 100 people vs. daily new COVID-19 deaths per million people. All doses, including boosters, are counted individually. Due to varying protocols and challenges in the attribution of the cause of death, the number of confirmed deaths may not accurately represent the true number of deaths caused by COVID-19.

Although survival of infants at 22 to 23 weeks gestation is no longer exceptional, mortality rates are high. In 2015, one-third of infants born at 22 to 23 weeks of gestation survived. Data for live births in such an early period of gestation was generally not recorded in statistical summaries prior to 2014.

title: Usage of improved water sources

subtitle: Improved drinking water sources include piped water on premises (piped household water connection located inside the user’s dwelling, plot or yard), and other improved drinking water sources (public taps or standpipes, tube wells or boreholes, protected dug wells, protected springs, and rainwater collection).

title: Average ammonium concentration in freshwater
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/average-ammonium-concentration-in-freshwater?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Annual mean concentration of ammonium in groundwater, lakes, and rivers. Sources of excess ammonium include agricultural runoff and municipal and industrial wastewater. At high concentrations, ammonium can be toxic to aquatic organisms.

title: Average nitrate concentration in freshwater
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/average-nitrate-concentration-in-freshwater?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Annual mean concentrations of nitrate in groundwater, lakes, and rivers. Sources of excess nitrate include agricultural runoff, sewage and wastewater, and industrial discharge.

title: Average phosphorus concentration in freshwater
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/average-phosphorus-concentration-in-freshwater?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Annual mean concentrations of phosphorus in groundwater, lakes, and rivers. Sources of excess phosphorous include agricultural runoff, sewage, soil erosion, and industrial wastewater.

title: Bathing sites with excellent water quality
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/bathing-sites-with-excellent-water-quality?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The percentage of coastal and inland bathing sites with 'excellent' water quality. To be classified as 'excellent' bathing sites must have levels of bacteria that are associated with sewage pollution below a defined threshold.

title: Death rate attributable to unsafe water, sanitation, and hygiene
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/mortality-rate-attributable-to-wash?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Death rate attributed to unsafe water, unsafe sanitation or lack of hygiene (WASH), measured as the number of deaths per 100,000 people of a given population.

title: Death rate from no access to hand-washing facilities
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/death-rates-no-handwashing?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Estimated annual number of deaths attributed to a lack of access to hand-washing facilities per 100,000 people.

title: Death rate from unsafe sanitation
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/death-rate-from-unsafe-sanitation?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Estimated annual number of deaths attributed to unsafe sanitation per 100,000 people. This is calculated as the 'attributable burden'. Attributable burden represents the reduction in deaths if a population's exposure had shifted from unsafe to adequate sanitation facilities.

title: Death rate from unsafe water sources
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/death-rates-unsafe-water?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Estimated annual number of deaths attributed to unsafe water sources per 100,000 people.

title: Death rate from unsafe water vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/death-rates-unsafe-water-vs-gdp?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Death rates are measured as the number of deaths per 100,000 individuals. GDP per capita is measured in constant international-$, which corrects for inflation and price differences between countries.

title: Deaths attributed to lack of access to handwashing facilities
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/deaths-due-to-lack-of-access-to-hand-washing-facilities?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Estimated annual number of deaths attributed to lack of access to handwashing facilities. Here the attributable burden is the number of deaths that would no longer occur if the entire population had access to a handwashing station with available soap and water.

title: Deaths attributed to unsafe sanitation
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/deaths-due-to-unsafe-sanitation?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Estimated annual number of deaths attributed to unsafe sanitation. Here the attributable burden is the number of deaths that would no longer occur if the entire population had access to high-quality piped water.

title: Deaths attributed to unsafe water sources
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/deaths-due-to-unsafe-water-sources?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Estimated annual number of deaths attributed to unsafe water sources. Here the attributable burden is the number of deaths that would no longer occur if the entire population had access to high-quality piped water.

title: Diarrheal disease episodes vs. safely managed sanitation
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/incidence-of-diarrheal-episodes-vs-access-to-improved-sanitation?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Diarrheal episodes per 100,000 people. Safely managed sanitation is defined as single-household improved sanitation facilities where excreta are safely disposed in situ or transported and treated off-site.

title: Diarrheal diseases death rate in children vs. access to basic handwashing facilities
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/diarrheal-diseases-vs-handwashing-facilities?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Estimated annual number of deaths from diarrheal diseases per 100,000 children under five, versus the percentage of people with access to basic handwashing facilities, including soap and water.

subtitle: Urban population using the five different levels of drinking water services: safely managed; basic, limited, unimproved and surface water.

title: Has country already reached SDG target for usage of improved sanitation facilities?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/sdg-target-for-access-to-sanitation?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Target 6.2 of the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is to achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all. Here we mark a cut-off threshold of 99% of the population using improved sanitation facilities.

title: Has country already reached SDG target on improved water access?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/sdg-target-on-improved-water-access?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Target 7.1 of the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is to achieve universal and equitable usage of safe and affordable drinking water for all. Here, we assume a target threshold of at least 99% using an improved water source.

title: Implementation of integrated water resource management
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/implementation-of-integrated-water-resource-management?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Integrated water resource management (IWRM) is a process which promotes the coordinated development and management of water, land and related resources in order to maximise economic and social welfare in an equitable manner without compromising the sustainability of vital ecosystems.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/improved-water-sources-vs-gdp-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: An improved drinking water source includes piped water on premises and other sources (public taps or standpipes, tube wells or boreholes, protected dug wells, protected springs, and rainwater collection). GDP per capita is measured in constant international-$.

subtitle: Open defecation refers to defecating in the open, such as in fields, forests, bushes, open bodies of water, on beaches, in other open spaces, or disposed of with solid waste.

subtitle: Improved drinking water sources are those that have the potential to deliver safe water by nature of their design and construction, and include: piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, rainwater, and packaged or delivered water.

title: People in rural areas not using improved sanitation facilities
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/rural-without-improved-sanitation?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation

title: People not using an improved water source
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-without-improved-water?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Improved drinking water sources are those that have the potential to deliver safe water by nature of their design and construction, and include: piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, rainwater, and packaged or delivered water.

title: People not using improved sanitation facilities
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-without-access-to-improved-sanitation?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Improved sanitation facilities are those designed to hygienically separate excreta from human contact, and include: flush/pour flush toilets connected to piped sewer systems, septic tanks or pit latrines; pit latrines with slabs (including ventilated pit latrines), and composting toilets.

title: People not using safe drinking water facilities
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-without-safe-drinking-water?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Safely managed drinking water is defined as an “Improved source located on premises, available when needed, and free from microbiological and priority chemical contamination.”

title: People not using to safely managed sanitation
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/safe-sanitation-without?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Safely managed sanitation is improved facilities which are not shared with other households and where excreta are safely disposed in situ or transported and treated off-site.

subtitle: Basic drinking water services are defined as an improved drinking water source, provided collection time is not more than 30 minutes for a roundtrip including queuing.

title: Various measures of national saving/investment compared to GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/various-measures-of-national-savinginvestment-compared-to-gdp-per-capita-in-international-dollars?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: GDP (gross domestic product) represents a nation's total income. The rest of the variables are various measures of national saving and investment, or in other words, changes in total wealth.

title: Contraceptive prevalence: modern methods vs. any methods
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/contraceptive-prevalence-any-methods-vs-modern-methods?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Data compiled from multiple sources by World Bank

title: Fertility rate vs. contraceptive prevalence
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fertility-vs-contraception?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The fertility rate, expressed as the number of children per woman, is based on age-specific fertility rates in one particular year. Contraceptive prevalence is the percentage of women who are practicing, or whose sexual partners are practicing, any form of contraception.

title: Fertility rate vs. unmet need for contraception
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fertility-vs-unmet-contraception?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The fertility rate, expressed as the number of children per woman, is based on age-specific fertility rates in one particular year. The unmet need for contraception shows the estimated share of married fertile women of reproductive age who do not want to become pregnant and are not using contraception.

title: Share of women using contraceptives
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/contraceptive-prevalence-any-methods-of-women-ages-15-49?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Contraceptive prevalence rate is the percentage of women who are practicing, or whose sexual partners are practicing, any form of contraception. It is usually measured for women ages 15-49 who are married or in union.

title: Women who make their own informed decisions regarding sexual relations, contraceptive use and reproductive health care
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/women-informed-decisions-health-sexual-relations?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Women aged 15-49 (married or in union) who can say no to sexual intercourse with their husband or partner if they do not want, decide on use of contraception, and decide on their own health care.

title: Average rating of perceived corruption in public sector

subtitle: Average of all individuals' perception ratings on a scale from 1 (corruption is not a problem) to 5 (corruption is a very serious problem).

title: Bribe payers index
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/bribe-payers-index?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Index constructed from surveys asking business executives for their perceptions of the likelihood of companies, from countries they have business dealings with, to engage in bribery. A score of 0 corresponds with the perceptions that companies always pay bribes when doing business abroad.

title: Bribery incidence for firms

title: Bribery prevalence

subtitle: Proportion of persons who had at least one contact with a public official in the previous year and who paid a bribe to them or were asked to do so.

title: Bribery rates

subtitle: Attainable yields are feasible crop yields based on outputs from high-yielding areas of similar climate. They are more conservative than absolute biophysical ‘potential yields’, but are achievable using current technologies and management (e.g. fertilizers and irrigation). Corn (maize) yields are measured in tonnes per hectare.

title: Corn: Yield gap

subtitle: Yield gaps measure the difference between actual yields and attainable yields. Attainable yields are more conservative than absolute biophysical ‘potential yields’, but are achievable using current technologies and management (e.g. fertilizers and irrigation). Corn (maize) yields are measured in tonnes per hectare.

title: What has driven the growth in global agricultural production?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-agri-productivity-growth?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Global agricultural growth is measured by the average annual change in economic output from agriculture. This is broken down by its drivers in each decade. Productivity growth measures increase output from a given amount of input: it's driven by factors such as efficiency gains, better seed varieties, land reforms, and better management practices.

title: Wheat yields

title: Stability of democratic institutions index

subtitle: Based on the expert estimates and index by the Bertelsmann Transformation Index (2024). It combines information on the extent to which democratic institutions are effective and efficient and all relevant actors accept them. It ranges from 1 to 10 (most stable).

title: Stateness index
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/stateness-index-bti?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Based on the expert estimates and index by the Bertelsmann Transformation Index (2024). It combines information on the extent to which the state has the monopoly on the use of force, provides basic public services across the country, citizens accept the state as legitimate, religious dogmas do not interfere, and citizenship is accessible. It ranges from 1 to 10 (high stateness).

title: Strong elected local governments index

subtitle: Based on the expert estimates and index by V-Dem. It combines information on the extent to which citizens elect regional governments which are free from influence of unelected regional actors except for courts. It ranges from 0 to 1 (strongest).

title: Rank in the Economic Complexity Index
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/economic-complexity-rankings?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The Economic Complexity Index (ECI) takes data on exports, and reduces a country’s economic system into two dimensions: (i) The number or ‘diversification’ of products in the export basket, and (ii) the quality, or ‘ubiquity’ of products in the export basket. This map ranks countries by ECI scores. The highest rank is 1 and corresponds to the country with the most complex economy in that year.

title: Access to electricity vs. GDP per capita

GDP per capita is adjusted for inflation and differences in the cost of living between countries.

subtitle: Exports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services provided to the rest of the world.

title: Annual growth of general government final consumption expenditure
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/annual-growth-of-general-government-final-consumption-expenditure?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: General government final consumption expenditure includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defense and security, but excludes expenditures that are part of government capital formation.

title: Annual growth of imports of goods and services
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/annual-growth-of-imports-of-goods-and-services?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Imports of goods and services represent the value of all goods and other market services received from the rest of the world. They include the value of merchandise, freight, insurance, transport, travel, royalties, license fees, and other services, such as communication, construction, financial, information, business, personal, and government services.

title: Annual growth of the gross capital formation
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/annual-growth-of-the-gross-capital-formation?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Gross capital formation consists of outlays on additions to the fixed assets of the economy and net changes in inventories. Fixed assets include land improvements, equipment purchases, and the construction of infrastructure and buildings. Inventories are goods held by firms to meet unexpected changes in production or sales.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/augmented-hdi-vs-gdp-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Automated teller machines (ATMs)

title: Bank capital to total assets ratio

Bank capital includes funds contributed by owners, retained earnings, general and special reserves, provisions, and valuation adjustments. Total bank assets include all non-financial and financial assets.

title: Broad money to total reserves ratio

subtitle: Broad money measures the amount of money circulating in an economy. Total reserves comprise holdings of monetary gold, special drawing rights, reserves of IMF members held by the IMF, and holdings of foreign exchange under the control of monetary authorities.

title: CO2 emissions per capita vs. GDP per capita

subtitle: Average incomes measured in national accounts are often much higher than those observed in survey data. See Roser and Hasell (2021) for further discussion.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/the-gender-wage-ratio-in-different-income-percentiles?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The gender ratio refers to the raw female-male wage ratio. "Ninetieth percentile" indicates an income higher than that of 90% of the population - thus, for example, in 2010 a 74% ratio in the ninetieth percentile indicates that the highest earning women made 74% of the hourly wage of the highest earning men.

title: The shrinking gender gap in high-level jobs and collective-bargaining coverage
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/the-shrinking-gender-gap-in-high-level-jobs-and-collective-barganing-coverage?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Each variable shows the difference between percent women minus percent men. I.e. in 1981, 21.5% of men and 9.2% of women held managerial jobs, amounting to a gender gap of 12.3%. 0% thus represents parity, and negative values indicate a higher incidence of women than men. “Male” professional jobs refer to those more often held by men and thus excluding nurses and K–12 and other non-college teachers.

title: Time spent on unpaid care and domestic work
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/time-spent-on-unpaid-care-and-domestic-work?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The average share of each day that women and men aged 15 and older, in urban and rural locations, spend on unpaid care and domestic work.

title: Unadjusted gender gap in average hourly wages
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/gender-gap-in-average-wages-ilo?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Gender wage gap, unadjusted for worker characteristics. Estimates correspond to the difference between average earnings of men and women, expressed as a percentage of average earnings of men.

title: Unadjusted gender gap in median earnings
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/gender-wage-gap-oecd?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The gender wage gap is unadjusted and is defined as the difference between median earnings of men and women relative to median earnings of men. Estimates refer to full-time employees and to self-employed workers.

title: Unadjusted gender wage gap including unemployed
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/unadjusted-gender-wage-gap-including-unemployed?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Shown are unadjusted pay gaps assigning zero income to individuals who are not employed. All figures correspond to women's income as a percent of men's, including wages and profits from self-employment.

subtitle: Displayed is the percentage of survey respondents who approved of wives working when asked the question: "Do you approve or disapprove of a married woman earning money in business or industry if she has a husband capable of supporting her?"

subtitle: This index is base on five underlying indicators: Labor policy and practice; Access to Finance; Education and training; Women's legal and social status; and the General business environment. Scores are scaled 0-100. Higher values denote more opportunities.

subtitle: Eutrophying emissions represent runoff of excess nutrients into the surrounding environment and waterways, which affect and pollute ecosystems. They are measured in grams of phosphate equivalents (PO₄eq).

subtitle: Eutrophying emissions represent runoff of excess nutrients into the surrounding environment and waterways, which affect and pollute ecosystems. They are measured in grams of phosphate equivalents (PO₄eq).

title: Excess nitrogen from croplands

subtitle: "Excess nitrogen" is the difference between nutrient inputs (from fertilizers, manure, and fixation from legumes) and the amount harvested in crop material. This represents nitrogen that are lost to the environment and can create ecological imbalances on ecosystems and in water bodies.

title: Excess nitrogen per hectare of cropland
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/excess-nitrogen-per-hectare?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: "Excess nitrogen" is the difference between nutrient inputs (from fertilizers, manure, and fixation from legumes) and the amount harvested in crop material. This represents nitrogen that is lost to the environment and can create ecological imbalances in ecosystems and water bodies.

subtitle: The food loss index measures the percentage of food lost from the farm level up until retail. It is compared to percentage losses in 2015. Values greater than 100 show increased waste since 2015; lower values indicate a decrease.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/risk-of-impoverishing-expenditure-for-surgical-care?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The proportion of population at risk of impoverishing expenditure when surgical care is required. Impoverishing expenditure is defined as direct out-of-pocket payments for surgical and anaesthesia care which drive people below the extreme poverty threshold.

title: Share of population with large expenditures on health
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-population-with-large-household-expenditures-on-health-10pc?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of the population that spend more than 10% of total household expenditure or income on health.

title: Share of population with very large expenditures on health
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/large-household-expenditures-health?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of the population that spend more than 25% of total household expenditure or income on health.

title: Share of small-scale industries with a loan or line of credit
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/smalsmall-scale-industries-loan?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: World Bank

title: Share of the population at risk of catastrophic expenditure when surgical care is required
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-the-population-at-risk-of-catastrophic-expenditure-when-surgical-care-is-required?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Catastrophic expenditure is defined as direct out-of-pocket payments for surgical and anaesthesia care exceeding 10% of total income.

title: Specialist surgical workforce rate
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/surgeons-per-100000?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Specialist surgical workforce is the number of specialist surgical, anaesthetic, and obstetric (SAO) providers who are working in each country per 100,000 population.

title: Tax revenue per capita and public health spending per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/tax-revenue-per-capita-and-public-health-spending-per-capita-in-developing-countries-in?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Tax revenue is defined as compulsory transfers to the central government for public purposes. Public expenditure on health care is defined as all the recurrent and capital spending from government, external borrowing and grants, and social health insurance funds. Both variables are measured in current international $, which adjusts for price differences between countries.

title: The Universal Health Coverage (UHC) Service Coverage Index
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/universal-health-coverage-index?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The Universal Health Coverage (UHC) Service Coverage Index is measured on a scale from 0 (worst) to 100 (best) based on the average coverage of essential services including reproductive, maternal, newborn and child health, infectious diseases, non-communicable diseases and service capacity and access.

title: Total assistance for development disbursed
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/total-assistance-for-development-by-donor?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total resource flows for development – including official development assistance and foreign direct investment – broken down by donor. This data is expressed in US dollars. It is not adjusted for inflation or differences in the cost of living between countries.

title: Total financial assistance and flows for agriculture, by recipient
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/total-financial-assistance-and-flows-for-agriculture-by-recipient?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total official development assistance (ODA) and other official flows from all donors to the agriculture sector. This data is expressed in US dollars. It is adjusted for inflation but does not account for differences in the cost of living between countries.

title: Total health expenditure per person
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/annual-healthcare-expenditure-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The sum of public and private annual health expenditure per person. This data is adjusted for differences in the cost of living between countries, but it is not adjusted for inflation.

title: Total healthcare expenditure as a share of GDP
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/total-healthcare-expenditure-gdp?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total healthcare expenditure as the share of national gross domestic product (GDP).

title: Total official development assistance for technical co-operation
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/total-official-development-assistance-for-technical-cooperation?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Technical co-operation official development assistance includes grants for education or training, and payments to consultants and similar personnel as well as teachers and administrators serving in recipient countries. This data is expressed in US dollars. It is adjusted for inflation but does not account for differences in the cost of living between countries.

title: US healthcare expenditure
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/us-healthcare-expenditure?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: National health expenditures expressed as a percent of GDP.

title: Annual fish catch relative to mean catch
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/annual-fish-catch-taxa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish catch is measured as annual catch divided by the mean catch over the stock's time series. A value greater than one means annual catch is higher than average over the entire time period.

title: Annual fish catch relative to mean catch by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-catch-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish catch is measured as annual catch divided by the mean catch over the stock's time series. A value greater than one means annual catch is higher than average over the entire time period.

title: Capture fishery production
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/capture-fishery-production?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Capture (wild) fishery production does not include seafood produced from fish farming (aquaculture).

title: Combatting illegal fishing
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/regulation-illegal-fishing?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Progress by countries in the degree of implementation of international instruments aiming to combat illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing (where 1 is lowest; 5 is highest).

title: Countries using ecosystem-based management of marine areas
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/countries-using-ecosystem-based-approaches-to-manage-marine-areas?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Ecosystem-based approaches consider the connections within an ecosystem, focusing on the importance of ecological integrity, biodiversity, social and economic factors and overall ecosystem health.

title: Fish and seafood production
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-seafood-production?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish and seafood production is measured as the sum of seafood from wild catch and fish farming (aquaculture).

title: Fish catch by fishing sector
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-catch-by-fishing-sector?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: FishStat via Pauly, Zeller, and Palomares from Sea Around Us Concepts, Design and Data.

title: Fish catch in the United Kingdom
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-catch-uk?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total annual landings – fish catch brought back to land – of bottom-living fish. This excludes shellfish.

title: Fish catch per unit of fishing power
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/catch-fishing-power-uk?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish catch is measured as the amount of landings – fish brought back to land – of bottom-dwelling fish. This is given per unit of fishing power: the number of fishing vessels multiplied by the fishing effort per vessel.

title: Fish discards
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-discards?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Discards are animals thrown back (alive or dead) into the sea after being caught during fishing activities. This represents bycatch (fish caught unintentionally) that is not brought ashore for use.

title: Fish landings and discards
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-landings-and-discards?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: – Landings represent aquatic animals that are caught and brought ashore for use. – Discards are animals thrown back (alive or dead) into the sea after being caught during fishing activities.

title: Fish stocks and fishing intensity by group
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-stocks-taxa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish stocks are measured by biomass: the number of individuals multiplied by their mass. Fishing intensity by the fraction of the fish population that is caught in a given year. Both are given as a ratio of their levels at the maximum sustainable yield – the level at which we can catch the maximum amount of fish without a decline in fish populations. A value of one maximises fish catch without decreasing fish populations. This is the target level.

title: Fish stocks and fishing intensity by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-stocks-by-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish stocks are measured by biomass: the number of individuals multiplied by their mass. Fishing intensity by the fraction of the fish population that is caught in a given year. Both are given as a ratio of their levels at the maximum sustainable yield – the level at which we can catch the maximum amount of fish without a decline in fish populations. A value of one maximises fish catch without decreasing fish populations. This is the target level.

title: Fishing intensity
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fishing-pressure-by-taxa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fishing intensity measured the extent to which a stock is being exploited. This is the fraction of the fish population that is caught in a given year. Here it's measured as the intensity divided by the intensity at the maximum sustainable yield – the level at which we can catch the maximum amount of fish without a decline in fish populations. A value of one is the optimal level to maximize fish catch without declining populations. Greater than one suggests overfishing.

title: Fishing intensity by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fishing-pressure-by-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fishing intensity measures the extent to which a stock is being exploited. Here, it's measured as current fishing intensity divided by the intensity at the maximum sustainable yield. A value of one is the optimal level to maximize fish catch without causing fish population. Greater than one suggests overfishing.

title: Five centuries of cod catches in Eastern Canada
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/long-term-cod-catch?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Estimates of North Atlantic cod (Gadus morhua) catch off Newfoundland and Labrador, Eastern Canada.

title: Freshwater use per kilogram of farmed seafood

subtitle: Based on a meta-analysis that includes data from 1690 fish farms. This is given per kilogram of edible weight. Chicken – the lowest-impact meat – is shown for comparison.

title: Global aquaculture production and wild fish used for animal feed
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-aquaculture-wild-fish-feed?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Some wild fish catch is processed into fishmeal and oils for animal feed – this is used for land-based livestock and fish farms (aquaculture). Efficiency improvements in aquaculture, and changes in the diets of farmed fish means production has increased rapidly, without increasing inputs from wild fish.

title: Global fish discards by type of fishing gear
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-discards-gear?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Discards are animals thrown back (alive or dead) into the sea after being caught during fishing activities.

title: Greenhouse gas emissions per kilogram of seafood
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/ghg-emissions-seafood?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Based on a meta-analysis of data from 1690 fish farms and 1000 unique fishery records. Impacts are given in kilograms of carbon dioxide-equivalents per kilogram of edible weight.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/biomass-fish-stocks-taxa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish stocks are measured by their biomass: the number of individuals multiplied by their mass. Here it's measured as the biomass of a fish stock divided by the biomass at its maximum sustainable yield – the level at which we can catch the maximum amount of fish without a decline in fish populations. A value of one maximises fish catch without decreasing fish populations.

title: Health of fish stocks by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/biomass-fish-stocks-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish stocks are measured by their biomass: the number of individuals multiplied by their mass. Here the biomass of a fish stock is divided by the biomass at its maximum sustainable yield. A value of one maximizes fish catch without decreasing fish populations.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-use-seafood?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Based on a meta-analysis of data from 1690 fish farms. Land use includes land used for aquaculture farms plus land for feed production. This is given per kilogram of edible weight. Chicken – the lowest-impact meat – is shown for comparison.

subtitle: Based on a meta-analysis of data from 1690 fish farms. Emissions are given in kilograms of nitrogen per tonne of edible weight. Chicken – the lowest-carbon meat – is shown for comparison.

title: Number of people employed in fisheries and aquaculture
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/employed-fisheries-aquaculture-time?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Number of people employed in fisheries and fish farms
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/employed-fisheries-aquaculture?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Phosphorous emissions per tonne of farmed seafood
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/phosphorous-emissions-seafood?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Based on a meta-analysis that includes data from 1690 fish farms. Emissions are given in kilograms of phosphorus per tonne of edible weight. Chicken – the lowest-carbon meat – is shown for comparison.

title: Protection of the rights of small-scale fisheries
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/protection-of-the-rights-of-small-scale-fisheries?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The implementation of frameworks which recognize and protect access rights for small-scale fisheries. The level of implemented protection is scored on a scale of 1 (lowest) to 5 (highest).

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/capture-fisheries-vs-aquaculture?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Aquaculture is the farming of aquatic organisms including fish, molluscs, crustaceans and aquatic plants. Capture fishery production is the volume of wild fish catches landed for all commercial, industrial, recreational and subsistence purposes.

title: Share of fish catch that is discarded by type of gear used
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-discard-rates-gear?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Share of fish stocks that are overexploited

title: Share of fish stocks within sustainable levels

It is an efficient way of catching fish, but has negative impacts on the ecology of the seabed. – Shown is the share of seabed across different regions that experienced at least one trawling pass over a period of two to four years around the year of 2010.

title: Annual food expenditure vs. total consumer expenditure

title: Average income of large-scale food producers
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/income-large-scale-food-producers?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Average income of small-scale food producers
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/income-small-scale-food-producers?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Cost of a calorie sufficient diet as a share of average food expenditure

subtitle: The cost of an energy sufficient diet is the cheapest way that an individual can meet their calorie requirement using available staple foods in each country.

title: Cost of a healthy diet as a share of average expenditure on food
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/cost-healthy-diet-share-food-expenditure?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Cost of a nutrient adequate diet as a share of average food expenditure

title: Daily cost of a calorie sufficient diet

subtitle: The cost of an energy sufficient diet is the cheapest way that an individual can meet their daily calorie requirement using available staple foods in each country. This data is adjusted for inflation and differences in the cost of living between countries.

title: Daily cost of a healthy diet

title: Daily cost of a nutrient adequate diet

title: Food expenditure as a share of family disposable income in the United States

title: Food expenditure per person

This data is expressed in US dollars per person. It is not adjusted for inflation or for differences in the cost of living between countries.

title: Food expenditure per person in the United States
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/food-expenditure-per-person?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Indicator of food price anomalies

subtitle: The indicator of food price anomalies measures monthly changes in food prices over many years, factoring in seasonal patterns and inflation.

title: Inflation of consumer prices

title: Long-term global prices of food commodities
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/long-term-prices-food?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Prices are measured relative to real prices in 1900 (where prices in 1900 are equal to 100).

title: Number of people that cannot afford a calorie sufficient diet
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-calorie-diet-unaffordable?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: A diet is deemed unaffordable if it costs more than 52% of a household's income. The cost of an energy-sufficient diet is the minimum cost to meet energy requirements using each country's lowest-cost starchy staple food.

title: Number of people that cannot afford a healthy diet
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-healthy-diet-unaffordable?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: A diet is deemed unaffordable if it costs more than 52% of a household's income. The cost of a healthy diet is defined as the lowest-cost set of items available that would meet requirements for each food group specified in food-based dietary guidelines from governments and public health agencies.

title: Number of people that cannot afford a nutrient adequate diet
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-nutritional-diet-unaffordable?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: A diet is deemed unaffordable if it costs more than 52% of a household's income. The cost of a nutrient adequate diet is defined as the lowest-cost set of items available at each time and place that would stay within the lower and upper bounds for dietary energy and all essential nutrients.
