title: Share of population that cannot afford a calorie sufficient diet
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-calorie-diet-unaffordable?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: A diet is deemed unaffordable if it costs more than 52% of a household's income. The cost of an energy sufficient diet is the cheapest way that an individual can meet their calorie requirement using available staple foods in each country.

title: Share of population that cannot afford a healthy diet
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-healthy-diet-unaffordable?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: A diet is deemed unaffordable if it costs more than 52% of a household's income. The cost of a healthy diet is the lowest-cost set of foods available that would meet requirements in dietary guidelines from governments and public health agencies.

title: Share of population that cannot afford a nutrient adequate diet
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-nutritional-diet-unaffordable?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: A diet is deemed unaffordable if it costs more than 52% of a household's income. The cost of a nutrient adequate diet is the lowest-cost set of foods available that would meet nutritional requirements of calories, protein, fats and all essential vitamins and minerals.

title: Transboundary animal breeds with conserved genetic material

title: Development assistance as share of government expense

subtitle: Shown is net official development assistance (ODA). These are disbursements of loans made on concessional terms (net of repayments of principal) and grants by official agencies of the members of the Development Assistance Committee (DAC), by multilateral institutions, and by non-DAC countries to promote economic development and welfare.

This data is expressed in US dollars. It is adjusted for inflation but does not account for differences in the cost of living between countries.

subtitle: Total resource flows for development – including official development assistance and foreign direct investment – broken down by recipient. This data is expressed in US dollars. It is not adjusted for inflation or differences in the cost of living between countries.

GDP per capita is measured in constant international-dollars which adjusts for inflation and cross-country price differences.

Deforestation embedded in imported goods measures deforestation in other countries caused in the production of food and forestry products which are imported. Countries which lie below the dashed line import deforestation at a higher rate than they are reforesting domestically.

subtitle: Countries are grouped into four forest transition phases which tend to represent a sequence of development. (1) Pre-transition: high forest cover and low deforestation rates; (2) Early-transition: forests lost at an increasingly rapid rate; (3) Late-transition: small fraction of remaining forest but slowing of deforestation; (4) Post-transition: forest cover increases through reforestation.

subtitle: Sex ratio at birth measures the number of male births per 100 female births. This is shown below by birth order of children i.e. the first, second or third-born child. Birth ratios are naturally male-biased, with an expected ratio of 105 male births per 100 female births.

title: Sex ratio at birth vs. at five years old

The grey line represents the point of equal ratio: countries which lie above this line had a higher sex ratio at birth than at five years old.

subtitle: Proportion of students achieving a minimum proficiency benchmark. Achievement outcomes come from standardized, psychometrically-robust international and regional tests. In order to maximize coverage by country, tests have been harmonized and pooled across subjects (math, reading, science) and levels (primary and secondary education). See source for details on proficiency benchmarks.

title: Share of students at the end of lower-secondary education achieving minimum math proficiency
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-students-at-end-of-lower-secondary-education-achieving-minimum-math-proficiency?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Minimum proficiency for the end of lower-secondary education is defined as: "Students demonstrate skills in number sense and computation, basic measurement, reading, interpreting, and constructing graphs, spatial orientation, and number patterns".

title: Share of students at the end of lower-secondary education with minimum reading proficiency
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-students-at-end-of-lower-secondary-education-with-minimum-reading-proficiency?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Minimum proficiency for the end of lower-secondary education is defined as: "Students establish connections between main ideas on different text types and the author’s intentions. They reflect and draw conclusions based on the text".

title: Share of students at the end of primary education achieving minimum math proficiency
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-students-at-end-of-primary-education-achieving-minimum-math-proficiency?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Minimum proficiency for the end of primary education is defined as: "Students demonstrate skills in number sense and computation, basic measurement, reading, interpreting, and constructing graphs, spatial orientation, and number patterns."

title: Share of students at the end of primary education achieving minimum reading proficiency
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-students-at-end-of-primary-education-achieving-minimum-reading-proficiency?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Minimum proficiency for the end of primary education is defined as: "Students interpret and give some explanations about the main and secondary ideas in different types of texts. They establish connections between main ideas on a text and their personal experiences as well as general knowledge".

title: Share of students from abroad
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-students-from-abroad?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: International students as a share of the country's overall tertiary enrolment. International students are those who move from their home countries for education, identified based on their past education, residence, or distinct immigration regulations.

title: Share of students in early primary education achieving minimum reading proficiency
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-students-in-early-primary-education-achieving-minimum-reading-proficiency?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Students in grades 2 or 3. Minimum proficiency for grade 2 is defined as: "They read and comprehend most of written words, particularly familiar ones, and extract explicit information from sentences". For grade 3 it is defined as: "Students read aloud written words accurately and fluently. They understand the overall meaning of sentences and short texts".

title: Share of students studying abroad

subtitle: Percentage of a country's tertiary level students studying abroad as international students. International students are those that move from their home countries for education, identified based on their past education, residence, or distinct immigration regulations.

subtitle: Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) per 100,000 individuals from all causes. DALYs measure the total burden of disease – both from years of life lost due to premature death and years lived with a disability. One DALY equals one lost year of healthy life.

title: Healthcare expenditure vs. GDP per capita

subtitle: Current healthcare expenditure per capita is adjusted for differences in the cost of living between countries but not for inflation. GDP per capita is adjusted for inflation and differences in the cost of living between countries.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/hearing-loss-by-age-group?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The estimated number of people with complete hearing loss, per 100,000 people in the population.

title: Hospital beds per 1,000 people
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/hospital-beds-per-1000-people?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Hospital beds include inpatient beds available in public, private, general, and specialized hospitals and rehabilitation centers. In most cases beds for both acute and chronic care are included.

title: Incidence of venomous animal contact

subtitle: Age-standardized incidence of a venomous animal contact, measured as the number of instances of venomous animal contact per 100,000 individuals. Venomous animals include all animals which deliver toxins as venom through a bite or sting.

subtitle: Nationally self-assessed scores for each of the 15 core capacities required to detect, assess, notify and respond to any potential public health events of international concern.

title: Leading broad cause of death
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/leading-broad-cause-of-death?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The leading causes of death broken down into three broad categories: infectious, maternal, neonatal, and nutritional diseases (e.g., HIV/AIDS, pre-term birth); non-communicable diseases (e.g., cardiovascular disease, cancer); and injuries (e.g., natural disasters, conflict).

title: Life expectancy
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/life-expectancy?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Life expectancy
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/life-expectancy-at-birth-who-gho?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The period life expectancy at birth, in a given year.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/life-expectancy-vs-healthcare-expenditure?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The period life expectancy at birth, in a given year. Healthcare expenditure per capita is measured in current international-$, which adjusts for price differences between countries.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/gini-coefficient-of-lifespan-inequality-in-females?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The level of inequality in lifespans within a country, measured between 0 and 1. A higher Gini coefficient indicates greater inequality in ages of death.

subtitle: The maternal mortality ratio is the estimated number of women who die from maternal conditions per 100,000 live births.

title: Medical doctors per 1,000 people
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/physicians-per-1000-people?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Multiple sources compiled by World Bank (2024)

subtitle: Countries are counted based on having mandatory or recommended vaccination for one or more childhood vaccines. Only countries where vaccination policy information was publicly available are shown.

title: Number of deaths
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-of-deaths?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Number of deaths
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-of-deaths-who?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

subtitle: Data source: IHME, Global Burden of Disease (2024)

title: Number of one-year-olds who have received different vaccinations

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/nurses-and-midwives-per-1000-people?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Multiple sources compiled by World Bank (2024)

title: People in rural areas not using an improved water source
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/rural-without-improved-water?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Improved drinking water sources are those that have the potential to deliver safe water by nature of their design and construction, and include: piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, rainwater, and packaged or delivered water.

title: Pharmaceutical personnel per 10,000 population
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/pharmaceutical-personnel-per-1000?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/population-unwpp?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Population by country, available from 10,000 BCE to 2100, based on data and estimates from different sources.

title: Reported cases of leprosy
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/reported-cases-of-leprosy?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Share in multidimensional poverty vs. Multidimensional Poverty Index

subtitle: Multidimensional poverty is defined as being deprived in a range of health, education and living standards indicators. The MPI is a measure that reflects both the prevalence and the intensity of multidimensional poverty.

title: Share in multidimensional poverty vs. Multidimensional Poverty Index
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-in-multidimensional-poverty-vs-multidimensional-poverty-index-hot?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Multidimensional poverty is defined as being deprived in a range of health, education and living standards indicators. The MPI is a measure that reflects both the prevalence and the intensity of multidimensional poverty.

title: Share of health facilities with essential medicines
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-health-facilities-with-essential-medicines?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

subtitle: An antenatal visit refers to pregnancy care provided by skilled health personnel (doctors, nurses or midwives).

subtitle: The share of mothers who received medical care in the first two days after giving birth.

title: Share of mothers visited by a health professional during pregnancy
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-mothers-receiving-at-least-one-antenatal-visit-during-pregnancy?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

subtitle: Lead paint is thought to be a significant contributor to lead poisoning; many countries have therefore implemented a regulatory limit of 90 parts per million (ppm) or 600ppm per weight of dry paint.

title: Share of paints with lead levels greater than 600 ppm
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/lead-paint-over-600ppm?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Lead paint is thought to be a significant contributor to lead poisoning; many countries have therefore implemented a regulatory limit of 90 parts per million (ppm) or 600ppm per weight of dry paint.

subtitle: The share of population with a National Accounts-based income lower than $2 per day, measured in 2011 international-$ (see Sources tab for details). The figures are adjusted for inflation and for price differences across countries.

title: Share of the population using safely managed sanitation facilities

subtitle: Specialist surgical workforce is the number of specialist surgical, anaesthetic, and obstetric (SAO) providers who are working in each country per 100,000 population.

title: The Universal Health Coverage (UHC) Service Coverage Index
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/universal-health-coverage-index?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The Universal Health Coverage (UHC) Service Coverage Index is measured on a scale from 0 (worst) to 100 (best) based on the average coverage of essential services including reproductive, maternal, newborn and child health, infectious diseases, non-communicable diseases and service capacity and access.

title: The burden of disease vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/the-burden-of-disease-vs-gdp-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The burden of disease is measured in Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs). DALYs measure the total burden of disease – both from years of life lost due to premature death and years lived with a disability. One DALY equals one lost year of healthy life. Here it is age-standardized and expressed per 100,000 individuals.

title: Total healthcare expenditure as a share of GDP
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/total-healthcare-expenditure-gdp?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

subtitle: Hospitalization data is available for individual UK nations, and English data by NHS Region. Data from the four nations may not be directly comparable as data about COVID-19 patients in hospitals are collected differently.

title: Government revenues as a share of GDP

subtitle: Taxes, social contributions, and other revenues such as fines, fees, rent, and income from property or sales included. Grants excluded.

title: Government revenues as a share of GDP
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/government-revenues-as-a-share-of-gdp-imf?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Taxes, social contributions, and other revenues such as fines, fees, rent, and income from property or sales included.

title: Share of government expenditure going to interest payments
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-government-expenditure-going-to-interest-payments?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Adequacy of social insurance programs
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/adequacy-of-social-insurance-programs?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Adequacy of social safety net programs

subtitle: Adequacy of social safety net programs is measured by the total transfer amount received by the population participating in social safety net programs as a share of their total welfare. Social safety net programs include cash transfers, social pensions, cash transfers, school feeding, and other social assistance programs.

title: Adequacy of unemployment benefits
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/adequacy-of-unemployment-benefits?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Adjusted net saving (current US dollars)
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/adjusted-net-saving-current-us-dollars?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Multiple sources compiled by World Bank (2024)

title: Agriculture orientation index for government expenditures
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/agriculture-orientation-index?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: A value greater than 1 means the agriculture sector receives a higher share of government spending relative to its economic value. A value less than 1 reflects a lower orientation to agriculture.

title: Annual broad money growth
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/annual-broad-money-growth?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Broad money is the sum of currency outside banks; demand deposits other than those of the central government; the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government; bank and traveler’s checks; and other securities such as certificates of deposit and commercial paper.

title: Annual budget of NASA
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/nasa-annual-budget?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: This data is expressed in US dollars, adjusted for inflation.

title: Annual growth of general government final consumption expenditure
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/annual-growth-of-general-government-final-consumption-expenditure?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: General government final consumption expenditure includes all government current expenditures for purchases of goods and services (including compensation of employees). It also includes most expenditures on national defense and security, but excludes expenditures that are part of government capital formation.

title: Annual growth of the gross capital formation
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/annual-growth-of-the-gross-capital-formation?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Gross capital formation consists of outlays on additions to the fixed assets of the economy and net changes in inventories. Fixed assets include land improvements, equipment purchases, and the construction of infrastructure and buildings. Inventories are goods held by firms to meet unexpected changes in production or sales.

title: Broad money to total reserves ratio
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/broad-money-to-total-reserves-ratio?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Broad money measures the amount of money circulating in an economy. Total reserves comprise holdings of monetary gold, special drawing rights, reserves of IMF members held by the IMF, and holdings of foreign exchange under the control of monetary authorities.

title: Central government expenditure as share of GDP
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/total-gov-expenditure-gdp-wdi?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total central government expenditures (payments for operating activities of the government in providing goods and services), as share of GDP.

title: Cultural and natural heritage expenditure per capita

title: Participation time in personal care per day

subtitle: Average minutes spent on personal care, per day, by individuals who participated in personal care activities. Estimates come from time use surveys and include both weekdays and weekends.

title: People who report having friends or relatives they can count on

title: Self-reported life satisfaction vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/gdp-vs-happiness?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Self-reported life satisfaction is measured on a scale ranging from 0-10, where 10 is the highest possible life satisfaction. GDP per capita is adjusted for inflation and differences in the cost of living between countries.

title: Share of people who say they are happy

title: Healthcare Access and Quality Index

subtitle: The Healthcare Access and Quality (HAQ) Index is measured on a scale from 0 (worst) to 100 (best) based on death rates from 32 causes of death that could be avoided by timely and effective medical care (also known as 'amenable mortality').

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/haq-by-level-of-healthcare-spending-endpoints?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Inequality in life expectancy

subtitle: The Atkinson index measures inequality on a scale from 0 to 1. Higher values indicate higher inequality. Inequality is measured here in terms of the number of years a newborn would live if age-specific mortality rates in the current year were to stay the same throughout its life.

title: Inequality in life expectancy vs. health expenditure per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/inequality-in-life-expectancy-vs-health-expenditure-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The Atkinson index measures inequality on a scale from 0 to 1. Higher values indicate higher inequality. Inequality is measured here in terms of the number of years a newborn would live if age-specific mortality rates in the current year were to stay the same throughout its life.

title: International health regulations capacities
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/ihr-core-capacity-index-sdgs?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Nationally self-assessed scores for each of the 15 core capacities required to detect, assess, notify and respond to any potential public health events of international concern.

title: The Universal Health Coverage (UHC) Service Coverage Index
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/universal-health-coverage-index?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The Universal Health Coverage (UHC) Service Coverage Index is measured on a scale from 0 (worst) to 100 (best) based on the average coverage of essential services including reproductive, maternal, newborn and child health, infectious diseases, non-communicable diseases and service capacity and access.

title: Coverage of essential health services
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/healthcare-access-quality-ihme?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Coverage of essential health services is measured as an index on a scale of 0 to 100 (where higher is better). This index is based on risk-standardized death rates – which give a measure of healthcare access and quality – and whether common interventions are carried out.

title: Critical care beds per 1,000 people

subtitle: Critical care beds are the sum of intensive care beds, and intermediate care beds (ICU and IMCU beds).

subtitle: Sheltered homeless are those staying in emergency shelters or transitional housing programs. Unsheltered homeless are those 'sleeping rough' (e.g. sleeping in parks).

subtitle: Population reported as experiencing homelessness at a single point in time per 100,000 people. The data is collected by counting the people living on the street or staying in shelters on one night of the year. Countries use different definitions and data collection methods and are harmonized to the extent possible.

title: Homelessness rate
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/homelessness-rate-flow-count?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

The data is collected by counting the people who at any point lived on the street or stayed in a shelter. Countries use different definitions and data collection methods and are harmonized to the extent possible.

Temporary accommodation is allocated to households with no permanent form of residence or who face immediate eviction. These figures are included in UK Government statistics on the prevalence of homelessness.

subtitle: A dispute can be understood as a problem between individuals or between individual(s) and an entity that gives rise to legal issues. Dispute resolution mechanisms include: lawyers, community or religious leaders, a court or tribunal, or the police.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-the-population-victim-to-physical-and-sexual-harassment?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

subtitle: Percentage of seats in lower or single chamber of the legislature held by women, weighted by countries' populations.

subtitle: This does not consider elections not being held, informal restrictions, or legal restrictions based on age, criminal conviction, disability, and local residency.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/women-civil-liberties-index?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Based on the expert estimates and index by V-Dem. It captures the extent to which women are free from forced labor, have property rights and access to the justice system, and enjoy freedoms of movement. The variables ranges from 0 to 1 (most rights).

title: Women's civil liberties index
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/women-civil-liberties-index-population-weighted?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Based on the expert estimates and index by V-Dem, weighted by countries' populations. It captures the extent to which women are free from forced labor, have property rights and access to the justice system, and enjoy freedoms of movement. The variables ranges from 0 to 1 (most rights).

title: Women's political empowerment index
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/women-political-empowerment-index?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Based on the expert estimates and index by V-Dem. It captures the extent to which women enjoy civil liberties, can participate in civil society, and are represented in politics. It ranges from 0 to 1 (most empowered).

title: Women's universal right to vote
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/universal-suffrage-women-lexical?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: This does not consider informal restrictions or legal restrictions based on age, criminal conviction, disability, and local residency.

title: Women, Business and the Law Index
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/women-business-and-the-law-index?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The index measures how laws and regulations affect women’s economic opportunity on a scale from 0 to 100, where 100 means equal legal rights for men and women. It is the average score of eight categories: mobility, workplace, pay, marriage, parenthood, entrepreneurship, assets and pension.

title: Global Hunger Index

subtitle: The Global Hunger Index tries to capture the multidimensional nature of hunger by calculating an index score from four key hunger indicators. It is measured on a 100-point scale where 0 is the best score (no hunger) and 100 is the worst.

title: Global Hunger Index vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-hunger-index-vs-gdp-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The Global Hunger Index is measured on a 100-point scale where 0 is the best (no hunger) and 100 the worst. GDP per capita is adjusted for inflation and differences in the cost of living between countries.

title: Inequality in per capita calorie intake

subtitle: The inequality in dietary calorie intake is measured as the coefficient of variation in energy intake. It represents the spread of intakes around the mean. Higher values represent larger levels of dietary inequality.

title: Inequality of food consumption vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/coefficient-of-variation-in-caloric-consumption-vs-gdp-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Inequality of food consumption is measured by the coefficient of variation in per capita caloric consumption. Higher values represent larger levels of dietary inequality. GDP per capita is measured in constant international-dollars.

subtitle: Protein-energy malnutrition (PEM) death rate, measured per 100,000 individuals versus gross domestic product (GDP) per capita, measured in constant international-$. PEM occurs as a result of insufficient caloric or protein intake.

subtitle: The share of children younger than five years old that are defined as stunted. Stunting is when a child is significantly shorter than the average for their age, as a consequence of poor nutrition and/or repeated infection.

title: Malnutrition: Share of children who are underweight
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-children-underweight?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

subtitle: Severe food insecurity is defined by the Food Insecurity Experience Scale (FIES). It is strongly related to insufficient quantity of food (energy).

title: Share of population with moderate or severe food insecurity

subtitle: Food insecurity is defined by the Food Insecurity Experience Scale (FIES). Moderate food insecurity is associated with the inability to regularly eat healthy, nutritious diets. Severe food insecurity is more related to insufficient quantity of food (energy).

title: Share of population with severe food insecurity

subtitle: This includes all jobs in unregistered and/or small-scale private unincorporated enterprises that produce goods or services meant for sale or barter. Self-employed street vendors, taxi drivers and home-base workers, regardless of size, are all considered enterprises.

Estimates come from the European Union Labour Force Survey (EU-LFS), years 2006-2008.

title: Unemployment rate

subtitle: Total areal land use for agriculture, measured as the combination of land for arable farming (cropland) and grazing in hectares.

title: Agricultural land per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/agricultural-area-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Agricultural land use

subtitle: Agricultural land use is the sum of croplands and pasture – land used for grazing livestock.

title: Agricultural land use per person
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/total-agricultural-land-use-per-person?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: This dataset is showing estimates of the total agricultural land area – which is the combination of cropland and grazing land – per person. It is measured in hectares per person.

title: Arable land needed to produce a fixed quantity of crops
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/arable-land-pin?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Arable land needed to produce a fixed quantity of crops is calculated as arable land divided by the crop production index (PIN). The crop production index (PIN) here is the sum of crop commodities (minus crops used for animal feed), weighted by commodity prices. This is measured as an index relative to 1961 (where 1961 = 1).

title: Arable land use per person
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/arable-land-use-per-person?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Arable land is defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops, temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow. It is measured in hectares per person.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/area-land-needed-to-global-oil?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: This metric represents the amount of land needed to grow a given crop if it was to meet global vegetable oil demand alone.

title: Breakdown of habitable land area

subtitle: Habitable land is defined as ice- and barren-free land. Agricultural land is the sum of croplands and pasture for grazing.

subtitle: The extent of intensive agriculture is defined as ‘minimal’ (less than 1% of land area); ‘common’ (1 to 20% of land area) or ‘widespread’ (more than 20%).

title: Has the world passed peak agricultural land?

title: How much cropland has the world spared due to increases in crop yields?

title: Land used for agriculture
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-use-agriculture-longterm?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Agricultural land use is the sum of croplands and pasture – land used for grazing livestock. It is measured in hectares.

title: Organic agricultural area
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/organic-agricultural-area?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total organic area is defined as the land area certified as organic, or in the conversion process to organic (over a two-year period). It is the portion of land area (including arable lands, pastures or wild areas) managed (cultivated) or wild harvested in accordance with specific organic standards.

title: Projections for global peak agricultural land
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/projections-for-global-peak-agricultural-land?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Projected trends in global agricultural area extent by various sources, measured in hectares. Projections include those from the UN Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO), International Assessment of Agricultural Knowledge, Science and Technology for Development (IAASTD); OECD, and scenarios from the Millennium Ecosystem Assessment (MEA). Also shown is the actual agricultural area to 2014, as reported by the UN FAO.

title: Share of adults who perceive their rights to land as secure
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-adults-who-perceive-their-rights-to-land-as-secure?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The landholder is considered to perceive their land rights as secure if they both: i) do not report a fear of involuntary loss of the land within the next five years, and ii) report having the right to bequeath the land.

title: Share of adults with legal documentation of their rights to land
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/legally-recognized-rights-to-land?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The proportion of the total adult population with secure tenure rights to land, recognized with legal documentation.

title: Share of arable land which is organic
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-arable-land-which-is-organic?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Organic arable land area is the sum of the area certified as organic by official standards, and land area in the conversion process to organic (which is assumed by the UN FAO as a two-year period prior to certification). Arable land is that used for crops (which does not include grazing land).

title: Share of deforestation that is driven by domestic consumption
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-deforestation-domestic-consumption?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of national deforestation that is driven by the production of goods that are consumed within domestic markets i.e. not exported to other countries.

title: Share of global habitable land needed for agriculture if everyone had the diet of...
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-global-habitable-land-needed-for-agriculture-if-everyone-had-the-diet-of?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The percentage of global habitable land area needed for agriculture if the total world population was to adopt the average diet of any given country. Values greater than 100% are not possible within global land constraints.

title: Share of land area used for agriculture
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-land-area-used-for-agriculture?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of land area used for agriculture, measured as a percentage of total land area. Agricultural land refers to the share of land area that is arable, under permanent crops, and under permanent pastures.

title: Share of land area used for arable agriculture
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-land-area-used-for-arable-agriculture?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of land area used for arable agriculture, measured as a percentage of total land area. Arable land includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow.

title: Share of land covered by lakes and rivers
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-land-covered-by-lakes-and-rivers?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The percentage of total land area that is made up of lakes and rivers all year round.

title: Share of land defined as natural habitat
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-natural-share?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Natural ecosystems include forest, grassland, savanna, and shrublands, and other classes such as peatlands and marshes. It is total land minus land that is used by humans for agriculture – either croplands or pasture – or for infrastructure and urban environments.

title: Share of land that is degraded
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-degraded-land?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Land degradation is defined as the reduction or loss of the biological or economic productivity of land resulting from a combination of pressures, including land use and management practices.

title: Share of land used for permanent meadows and pastures
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/area-meadows-and-pastures?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Permanent meadows and pastures is defined by the FAO as: "the land used permanently (five years or more) to grow herbaceous forage crops, either cultivated or growing wild (wild prairie or grazing land)."

title: Share of mountain land that is degraded
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-mountain-land-that-is-degraded?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Degraded land is land that has lost biological or economic productivity and complexity due to pressures from land use or management practices.

title: Share of rural land area where the elevation is 5 meters or less
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/rural-land-below-5-meters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Multiple sources compiled by World Bank (2024)

title: Share of world regions with land use present
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-regions-with-land-use?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Stephens et al. (2019). Archaeological assessment reveals Earth’s early transformation through land use. Science.

title: Terrain Ruggedness Index
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/terrain-ruggedness-index?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Indicates how jagged or flat the terrain of a country is on average. Ruggedness is measured in metres of elevation difference for grid points 30 arc-seconds (926 metres on the equator or any meridian) apart.

title: Tractors per 100 square kilometers of arable land
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/tractors-per-100-square-kilometers-of-arable-land?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Tractors used in agriculture per 100 square kilometers of arable land.

title: Agricultural area over the long-term
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/total-agricultural-area-over-the-long-term?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total areal land use for agriculture, measured as the combination of land for arable farming (cropland) and grazing in hectares.

title: Agricultural land per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/agricultural-area-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Agricultural land is the sum of cropland and land used as pasture for grazing livestock.

title: Agricultural land use per person
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/total-agricultural-land-use-per-person?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: This dataset is showing estimates of the total agricultural land area – which is the combination of cropland and grazing land – per person. It is measured in hectares per person.

title: Arable land needed to produce a fixed quantity of crops
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/arable-land-pin?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Arable land needed to produce a fixed quantity of crops is calculated as arable land divided by the crop production index (PIN). The crop production index (PIN) here is the sum of crop commodities (minus crops used for animal feed), weighted by commodity prices. This is measured as an index relative to 1961 (where 1961 = 1).

title: Arable land use per person
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/arable-land-use-per-person?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Arable land is defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops, temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow. It is measured in hectares per person.

subtitle: Total cropland area, measured in hectares. Cropland refers to the area defined by the UN Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO) as 'arable land and permanent crops'.

title: Cropland per person over the long-term
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/cropland-per-person-over-the-long-term?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

subtitle: The share of global habitable land which would be required for agriculture if everyone in the world adopted the average diet of a given country versus gross domestic product (GDP) per capita, measured in constant international-$. We currently use approximately 50% of habitable land for agriculture, as shown by the horizontal line.

subtitle: Total organic area is defined as the land area certified as organic, or in the conversion process to organic (over a two-year period). title: Lead concentrations in the blood of children in the United States
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/lead-blood-usa-children?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Lead concentrations measured in blood samples from children aged one to five years old. Children are particularly vulnerable to lead poisoning and can suffer permanent impacts on the development of the brain and nervous system.

title: Mean lead concentrations in the blood of adults
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/lead-concentrations-blood-adults?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Mean lead concentrations in the blood of adults aged 14 and over between 2010 and 2019. There is no defined 'safe' level for lead blood concentrations. The WHO adopts a threshold of 5 µg/dL as an achievable maximum level.

title: Mean lead concentrations in the blood of children
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/lead-concentrations-blood-children?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Number of children with lead levels in blood greater than 10 µg/dL
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/children-lead-10micrograms?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Children are defined as those aged 0 to 14 years old. There is no defined 'safe' level for lead blood concentrations. The WHO adopts a threshold of 5 µg/dL as an achievable maximum level in children.

title: Number of children with lead levels in blood greater than 5 µg/dL
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/children-lead-5micrograms?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Rate of disease burden from lead exposure

subtitle: Disease burden is measured in disability-adjusted life years (DALYs). DALYs include the years of life lost due to premature death and years lived with a disability. One DALY equals one lost year of healthy life. This is expressed as a rate per 100,000 people.

subtitle: Antibiotics are used in livestock for animal health and productivity, but also pose a risk for antibiotic resistance in both humans and livestock. Data is measured as the milligrams of total antibiotic use per kilogram of meat production. This is corrected for differences in livestock numbers and types, normalising to a population-corrected unit (PCU). A suggested global cap of antibiotic use in livestock is set at 50mg/PCU.

title: Global meat demand if everyone ate like the average citizen of...
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/hypothetical-global-meat-demand?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Hypothetical global meat demand if everyone in the world ate the same quantity as the average citizen of a given country. For example, data for the US in 2020 shows global meat demand if everyone in the world consumed the same amount of meat as the average US citizen in 2020. The curve for "World" gives the actual global meat production in 2020.

subtitle: The protein efficiency of meat and dairy production is defined as the percentage of protein inputs as feed effectively converted to animal product. A value of 3.9 for PTSD, for example, would indicate that individuals with PTSD are 3.9 times as likely to develop drug dependency relative to those without.

title: Hidden Hunger Index in pre-school children

title: Hidden Hunger Index vs. GDP per capita

title: Hidden Hunger Index vs. share in extreme poverty

subtitle: The monetary value of total or partial destruction of physical assets existing in the affected area from natural disasters, as a share of gross domestic product (GDP).

title: Disaster risk reduction progress score
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/disaster-risk-reduction-progress?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Disaster risk reduction progress score is an average of self-assessment scores, ranging from 1 to 5 (where 5=best). Assessments include four indicators that reflect the degree to which countries have prioritized disaster risk reduction and the strengthening of relevant institutions.

title: Drought severity index in the United States
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/drought-severity-index-us?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The Palmer Drought Severity Index is the most widely used index to measure drought severity over time. An index value of zero represents the average moisture conditions observed between 1931 and 1990. Positive values mean wetter than average, negatives mean drier than average.

title: Economic damage by natural disaster type
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/economic-damage-from-natural-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Global economic damage from natural disasters, differentiated by disaster category and measured in US$ per year.

title: Economic damages from disasters as a share of GDP
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/economic-damages-from-natural-disasters-as-a-share-of-gdp?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: EM-DAT, CRED / UCLouvain (2024); Multiple sources compiled by World Bank (2024)

title: Fatality rates due to lightning in the US
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fatality-rates-due-to-lightning-in-the-us?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Annual death rate per million

title: Fatality rates in the US due to weather events
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fatality-rates-in-the-us-due-to-weather-events?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Annual death rate from weather events, measured per million individuals.

title: Global damage costs from natural disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/damage-costs-from-natural-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total economic cost of damages as a result of global natural disasters in any given year, measured in current US$. Includes those from drought, floods, extreme weather, extreme temperature, landslides, dry mass movements, wildfires, volcanic activity and earthquakes.

title: Global injuries from natural disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-injured-from-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Global number of people injured from natural disaster events. This is defined as "people suffering from physical injuries, trauma or an illness requiring immediate medical assistance as a direct result of a disaster."

title: Global natural disaster death rates
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/natural-disaster-death-rates?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Death rates from natural disasters are measured as the number of deaths per 100,000 individuals.

title: Global number of reported disasters by size
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/natural-disasters-by-yearly-impact?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: ‘Small’ events have 5 or fewer deaths, less than 1,500 people affected, or reported economic damages below US$13 million. ‘Large’ events have at least 50 deaths, more than 150,000 people affected, or reported economic damages of at least US$320 million. At least part of the increase in small and medium reported events is due to improved reporting over time.

title: Global number of reported disasters by size per decade
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/natural-disasters-by-decadal-size?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: ‘Small’ events have 5 or fewer deaths, less than 1,500 people affected, or reported economic damages below US$13 million. ‘Large’ events have at least 50 deaths, more than 150,000 people affected, or reported economic damages of at least US$320 million. At least part of the increase in small and medium reported events is due to improved reporting over time.

title: Global number of reported natural disasters by the number of deaths
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/natural-disasters-reported-by-deaths?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The number of disaster events recorded in the EM-DAT disaster database, broken down by the size of the event, in terms of deaths. There has been an increase in the number of the smallest events – with over 200 deaths – at least partly due to improvements in recording over time.

title: Global precipitation anomaly
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-precipitation-anomaly?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: This indicator shows annual anomalies compared with the average precipitation from 1901 to 2000 based on rainfall and snowfall measurements from land-based weather stations worldwide.

title: Global reported natural disasters by type
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/natural-disasters-by-type?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The annual reported number of natural disasters, categorised by type. The number of global reported natural disaster events in any given year. Note that this largely reflects increases in data reporting, and should not be used to assess the total number of events.

title: Global weather disaster losses as a share of GDP
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/weather-losses-share-gdp?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Global disaster losses from weather- and climate-related events in economic terms, expressed as a share of global gross domestic product (GDP). Economic loss data from disasters is based on figures reported by Munich Re.

title: How many deaths does it take for a disaster in different continents to receive news coverage?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/how-many-deaths-does-it-take-for-a-disaster-in-different-continents-to-receive-news-coverage?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Disaster occurrence and news coverage data is used to compute the casualties ratio. The casualties ratio indicates how many casualties would make media coverage (in major US networks) equally likely, all else equal.

title: How many deaths does it take for a disaster to receive news coverage?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/how-many-deaths-does-it-take-for-a-disaster-to-receive-news-coverage?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Disaster occurrence and news coverage data is used to compute the casualties ratio. The casualties ratio indicates how many casualties would make media coverage (in major US networks) equally likely, all else equal.

title: Hurricane landfalls in the United States
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/hurricane-landfalls-us?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Hurricanes are categorised by the Saffir–Simpson hurricane wind scale (SSHWS) which classifies by five categories (1 being the lowest; 5 the highest). Hurricanes reaching Category 3 and higher are considered major hurricanes because of their potential for significant loss of life and damage.

title: Near-Earth asteroids discovered over time
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/near-earth-asteroids-discovered-over-time?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Cumulative number of discovered asteroids with an orbit that brings them into proximity with Earth. This is broken down by size of the asteroid.

title: News coverage of disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/news-coverage-of-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The data considers disasters occurring between 1968-2002 and their corresponding coverage in major US networks. It is evident that "spectacular" disasters receive more coverage.

title: News coverage of disasters, by continent
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/news-coverage-of-disasters-by-continent?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The data considers disasters occurring between 1968-2002 and their corresponding coverage in major US networks.

title: Number of North Atlantic hurricanes
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/frequency-north-atlantic-hurricanes?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Major hurricanes are defined as those of category 3, 4 or 5 on the Saffir–Simpson hurricane wind scale (SSHWS). The SSHWS classifies storms based on the intensity of sustained winds. Major hurricanes have potential for significant loss of life and damage.

title: Number of deaths from natural disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-of-deaths-from-natural-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: EM-DAT, CRED / UCLouvain (2024)

title: Number of deaths from natural disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/natural-disaster-deaths-ihme?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Annual number of deaths from all forms of natural disasters.

title: Number of deaths from natural disasters by type
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/deaths-from-natural-disasters-by-type?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Global estimates of the number of deaths from natural disasters, differentiated by disaster type.

title: Number of local governments with disaster risk reduction strategies
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/local-govts-risk-reduction?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Number of local governments that have adopted and implemented local disaster risk reduction strategies in line with the national strategy.

title: Number of recorded natural disaster events
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-of-natural-disaster-events?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The number of global reported natural disaster events in any given year. Note that this largely reflects increases in data reporting, and should not be used to assess the total number of events.

title: Number of significant earthquakes
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/significant-earthquakes?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: A significant earthquake meets at least one of the following: caused deaths, moderate damage ($1 million or more), a magnitude 7.5 or greater, Modified Mercalli Intensity (MMI) X or greater, or generated a tsunami. Due to data availability, recent data will be more complete than older historical estimates.

title: Number of significant volcanic eruptions
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/significant-volcanic-eruptions?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: A significant eruption is classified as one that meets at least one of the following criteria: caused fatalities, caused moderate damage (approximately $1 million or more), with a Volcanic Explosivity Index (VEI) of 6 or larger, caused a tsunami, or was associated with a major earthquake.

title: Number of tsunamis
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-of-tsunamis?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: National Geophysical Data Center / World Data Service (2024)

title: Number of wildfires in the United States
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/wildfire-numbers-usa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The number of wildfire events in the United States. Data is shown from 1983 onwards, when comparable data records began.

title: People affected by natural disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/total-affected-by-natural-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Global total number of people affected by natural disasters. This is defined as the sum of the injured, affected and those left homeless after a disaster.

title: People displaced internally by natural disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/internally-displaced-persons-from-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Internally-displaced persons are defined as people or groups of people who have been forced or obliged to flee or to leave their homes or places of habitual residence, as a result of natural or human-made disasters and who have not crossed an international border.

title: People left homeless from natural disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-homeless-from-natural-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Global number of people left homeless from natural disaster events. This is defined as "number of people whose house is destroyed or heavily damaged and therefore need shelter after an event."

title: Precipitation anomaly in the United States
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/precipitation-anomaly?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Annual anomalies compared with the average precipitation from 1901 to 2000 based on rainfall and snowfall measurements from land-based weather stations. Anomalies across all US states were then aggregated based on weighted averages (by area) to define a national result.

title: Projected number of air conditioning units
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/air-conditioners-projections?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

subtitle: Seasonal temperature anomaly, compared to the 1901–2000 average temperature. Measured in degrees Fahrenheit.

title: Share of US land that experienced extreme one-day precipitation
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/extreme-one-day-precipitation-usa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of land area in the United States that experienced an extreme single-day precipitation event.

title: Share of US land with unusually high annual precipitation
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/unusually-high-precipitation-usa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Share of land area in the United States which experienced unusually high annual precipitation in a given year. This compares actual yearly precipitation totals with expected totals based on historical data.

title: Share of US land with unusually high summer temperatures
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/high-summer-temp-usa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Unusually hot summers are defined based on daily maximum temperatures. At each station, the recorded highs are compared with the full set of historical records. After averaging over a particular month or season of interest, the warmest 10% of years are defined as “unusually hot”.

title: Share of US land with unusually low winter temperatures
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/low-winter-temps-usa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Unusually cold winter temperatures are measured based on daily minimum temperatures. At each station, the recorded lows are compared with the full set of historical records. After averaging over a particular month or season of interest, the coldest 10 percent of years are defined as “unusually cold.”

title: Share of deaths from natural disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-deaths-from-natural-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The estimated share of deaths from exposure to forces of nature.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/disaster-events-missing-data?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of disaster events recorded in the widely-cited EM-DAT database with missing data for a given metric. This was measured over the period from 1990 to 2020.

title: Share of households with air conditioning
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/households-air-conditioning?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: International Energy Agency (IEA). Future of Cooling.

title: Share of local governments that adopted and implemented local disaster risk reduction strategies in line with national strategies
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/local-gov-disaster-strategies?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: UN Office for Disaster Risk Reduction

title: Countries where buruli ulcer is endemic
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/status-of-buruli-ulcer-endemicity?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Share of one-year-olds who are vaccinated against polio

title: Share of one-year-olds who received the inactivated polio vaccine

subtitle: The inactivated polio vaccine (IPV1) protects children against polioviruses types 1, 2 and 3. IPV does not replace the Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV), but is used with OPV to strengthen a child’s immune system and protect them from polio.

title: Share of potential polio cases tested and reported to the WHO

title: Where are we falling behind on screening and testing for polio?

subtitle: Countries are considered to have adequate screening if they have a non-polio acute flaccid paralysis rate above 2 per 100,000 children, and adequate testing if they have a stool collection rate above 80%.

title: Share in extreme poverty vs. poverty gap index

subtitle: Extreme poverty is defined as living below the International Poverty Line of $2.15 per day. The poverty gap index is a poverty measure that reflects both the prevalence and the depth of poverty. It is the share of population in poverty multiplied by the average shortfall from the poverty line (expressed as a % of the poverty line).
